title: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially invited to join NATO and the invitation is accepted by the Ukrainian government. The invitation must be documented in an official NATO communiquÃ© or similar authoritative source. Additionally, the acceptance must be confirmed by a public statement from the President of Ukraine or the Ukrainian government. The resolution will also consider the status of Ukraine's membership in NATO if it has completed all necessary reforms and met the criteria for membership as outlined in NATO's Membership Action Plan. Any temporary or conditional invitations that do not lead to full membership by the specified date do not count towards a Yes resolution.

title: Will Ukraine receive a Membership Action Plan from NATO before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, NATO officially grants Ukraine a Membership Action Plan (MAP). The decision must be made during a NATO summit or through an official announcement from NATO's Secretary General or the North Atlantic Council. The Membership Action Plan must be recognized as a formal step towards NATO membership for Ukraine. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (such as BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the decision will suffice. Any informal discussions or intentions expressed by NATO officials do not count towards this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

title: Will Ukraine achieve full military interoperability with NATO forces by 2028?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, Ukraine achieves full military interoperability with NATO forces as defined by the following criteria: 1. Ukraine's armed forces must be fully integrated into NATO command structures, allowing for joint operations and decision-making. 2. Ukraine must have adopted NATO standards for military equipment, logistics, and operational procedures, as verified by NATO assessments. 3. Joint military exercises involving NATO and Ukrainian forces must demonstrate the capability to operate seamlessly together in a range of scenarios. 4. This interoperability must be publicly acknowledged by NATO officials and documented in official NATO reports. In the absence of such documentation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the achievement of interoperability will suffice.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

title: Will Ukraine hold a national referendum on NATO membership before 2027?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2027, Ukraine officially holds a national referendum regarding its membership in NATO. The referendum must be recognized by the Ukrainian government and conducted under the oversight of international observers to ensure fairness and legitimacy. The results of the referendum must be made publicly available and reported by reputable news sources such as BBC, The Guardian, or Reuters. Any preliminary discussions or proposals for a referendum do not count; the actual voting event must occur.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

title: Will NATO conduct joint military exercises with Ukraine before 2026?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if NATO conducts joint military exercises with Ukraine before January 1, 2026. A joint military exercise is defined as any coordinated military training operation involving personnel from both NATO member states and Ukraine that is officially announced and takes place on Ukrainian territory or in international waters involving Ukrainian forces. The exercise must be publicly confirmed by NATO or the Ukrainian government through an official statement or reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post). Any exercises that are part of a larger multinational operation or that do not include Ukrainian forces do not count towards this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

title: Will any NATO member state oppose Ukraine's membership before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, any NATO member state officially declares its opposition to Ukraine's membership in NATO. This opposition must be made through a formal statement by a government official or through an official communication from the NATO organization. The statement must explicitly mention opposition to Ukraine's membership and cannot be vague or ambiguous. Statements made in informal settings, such as interviews or social media, do not count unless they are later confirmed through official channels. In case of multiple statements, the first official declaration of opposition will determine the resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially scheduled to take place in a country that is currently under international sanctions imposed by recognized authorities such as the United Nations, the European Union, or the United States. The term 'international sanctions' refers to restrictions imposed on a country by the international community, which may include trade restrictions, financial embargoes, and travel bans. The hosting of the Grand Prix must be confirmed by an official announcement from Formula 1 or the relevant governing body. If the event is canceled or relocated for any reason, this question will resolve as No. Temporary or unofficial races do not count towards this resolution.

title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if a Formula 1 Grand Prix is hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by the end of 2030.

metadata.source_question: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?

title: Will a Formula 1 team be sponsored by a company based in a country under international sanctions by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if a Formula 1 team secures sponsorship from a company based in a country currently under international sanctions by the end of 2025.

metadata.source_question: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?

title: Will a Formula 1 driver participate in a race in a country under international sanctions by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if a Formula 1 driver competes in a race held in a country currently under international sanctions by the end of 2025.

metadata.source_question: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?

title: Will the FIA change its regulations to allow races in countries under international sanctions by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if the FIA modifies its regulations to permit Formula 1 races in countries currently under international sanctions by the end of 2025.

metadata.source_question: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?

title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be canceled due to political reasons in a sanctioned country by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if a Formula 1 Grand Prix is canceled because of political reasons related to the country's international sanctions by the end of 2025.

metadata.source_question: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?

title: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United States Senate has passed legislation that significantly alters or establishes new nuclear safety standards. Significant legislation is defined as any bill that: 
- Introduces new safety regulations for nuclear power plants, including but not limited to operational, environmental, or safety protocols. 
- Amends existing laws such as the Atomic Energy Act or the Nuclear Waste Policy Act in a way that enhances safety standards. 
The legislation must be officially signed into law by the President of the United States. The resolution will rely on official congressional records and reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) for verification. If multiple bills are introduced, at least one must be passed and signed into law for the resolution to be Yes.

title: Will the US House of Representatives pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the US House of Representatives has passed legislation that significantly alters nuclear safety standards. Significant alterations include, but are not limited to, changes to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's regulations, the introduction of new safety protocols, or amendments that increase safety requirements for nuclear power plants. The legislation must be officially signed into law by the President to count as passed. Legislation that merely proposes changes or is under consideration will not be sufficient for a Yes resolution. Reports from major news organizations (e.g., CNN, The Washington Post, NPR) confirming the passage of such legislation will be considered authoritative.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

title: Will there be a major public debate about nuclear safety standards in the US by 2024?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, there is a publicly accessible debate or forum involving key stakeholders (government officials, industry representatives, and public interest groups) specifically focused on nuclear safety standards in the United States. The debate must be covered by at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and must address issues such as regulatory changes, safety protocols, or public health concerns related to nuclear energy. If the debate occurs in a private setting or is not widely reported, the question will resolve as No. Additionally, any discussions that are purely academic or not aimed at public policy changes will not count towards this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

title: Will any US state implement stricter nuclear safety regulations than federal standards by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, any U.S. state has enacted nuclear safety regulations that are stricter than the current federal standards set by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). The regulations must be officially adopted and published in the state’s legislative records. The criteria for 'stricter' include any regulations that impose more rigorous safety requirements, limits, or protocols than those outlined in the federal regulations. The resolution will be based on official state government announcements, and the regulations must be in effect, not just proposed. In the case of multiple states adopting such regulations, the question will still resolve as Yes if at least one state meets the criteria.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

title: Will the US government allocate increased funding for nuclear safety research by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the US government has officially allocated an increase in funding for nuclear safety research compared to the funding levels in 2024. The increase must be documented in a federal budget proposal or an official announcement from a government agency such as the Department of Energy or the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The increase must be at least 10% over the 2024 funding levels. In the event of a budget proposal that includes increased funding but is subsequently rejected or altered, the question will still resolve as Yes if the initial proposal included the required increase.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

title: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the European Union has officially implemented a unified nuclear waste management policy that is recognized and adopted by all member states. The policy must include standardized procedures for the handling, storage, and disposal of nuclear waste across the EU, and it must be formally adopted through a legislative process involving the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union. The implementation must be confirmed by an official EU announcement or documentation. In the absence of such an announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient to confirm the policy's adoption. Temporary measures or pilot programs do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will any EU member state adopt a national nuclear waste management policy before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, any European Union member state has officially adopted a national policy for the management of nuclear waste. The policy must be publicly available and include provisions for the safe storage, disposal, and management of nuclear waste. The adoption must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In case multiple states adopt such a policy, the question still resolves as Yes if at least one state meets the criteria. Temporary measures or pilot programs do not count toward this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?

title: Will the European Union achieve a consensus on nuclear energy regulations by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the European Union has achieved a formal consensus on nuclear energy regulations that is publicly documented and recognized by all member states. This consensus must include agreement on key regulatory aspects such as safety standards, waste management, and operational protocols. The consensus must be confirmed through an official EU announcement or a resolution passed by the European Parliament. In the absence of such announcements, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) must indicate that a consensus has been reached. Any proposals or discussions that do not result in a formal agreement do not count towards this question's resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?

title: Will the European Union allocate funding for nuclear waste management initiatives by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the European Union has officially allocated funding for nuclear waste management initiatives through a formal decision or announcement. The funding must be specifically designated for projects aimed at the safe management, storage, or disposal of nuclear waste, and must be confirmed by official EU documentation or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). The allocation must be part of a recognized EU budget or financial framework, and not merely a proposal or discussion without formal commitment.

metadata.source_question: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?

title: Will there be a significant public protest against nuclear waste management policies in the EU by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a significant public protest against nuclear waste management policies in the European Union is reported. A 'significant public protest' is defined as a demonstration or gathering that attracts at least 5,000 participants in a major city within the EU, such as Paris, Berlin, Rome, or Madrid, and is covered by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). The protest must be explicitly focused on nuclear waste management policies and not on broader environmental issues. Protests that are part of smaller events or that do not meet the participant threshold will not count towards this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?

title: Will the European Union's nuclear waste management policy include provisions for recycling nuclear waste by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the European Union has officially adopted a nuclear waste management policy that includes specific provisions for the recycling of nuclear waste. The policy must outline clear methods for recycling, the technologies to be used, and a timeline for implementation. The resolution will be based on official EU documentation and announcements. The recycling provisions must be applicable to all member states and not limited to pilot projects or theoretical frameworks. The policy must also be recognized by relevant regulatory bodies within the EU, such as the European Commission or the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM). In the absence of official documentation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Reuters) will suffice to confirm the adoption of such provisions.

metadata.source_question: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is clear evidence of a significant increase in global soccer viewership attributed to the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams. Specifically, this will be measured by: 1. An increase of at least 20% in the average global viewership numbers for the World Cup compared to the previous tournament with 32 teams in 2018. 2. Official reports from FIFA or credible third-party sources (such as Nielsen or similar audience measurement organizations) confirming this increase. 3. The increase must be directly linked to the expanded format, meaning that viewership figures must show a correlation with the expansion and not be influenced by other factors (e.g., the popularity of specific teams or players). In the absence of clear data from FIFA, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, etc.) will suffice to confirm the increase.

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams result in a higher average attendance at matches by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the average attendance at matches during the FIFA World Cup, which will be held in 2026 with 48 teams, is higher than the average attendance recorded during the previous World Cup held in 2022. The average attendance will be calculated based on the total number of attendees across all matches divided by the number of matches played during the tournament. The attendance figures must be reported by FIFA and corroborated by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In case of any matches played without spectators or in empty stadiums, those matches will be excluded from the average attendance calculation.

metadata.source_question: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to an increase in the number of countries participating in the tournament by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, at least 10 new countries that have never previously qualified for the FIFA World Cup participate in the tournament following the expansion to 48 teams. These countries must qualify through the official FIFA qualification process for the World Cup, and their participation must be confirmed by FIFA in the official tournament records. The expansion must be in effect for at least one tournament prior to this date, and the qualification must be for the 2026 or 2030 World Cup. Countries that have previously participated in World Cup tournaments do not count as new participants.

metadata.source_question: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams have a positive impact on youth soccer participation rates globally by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is a recognized increase in youth soccer participation rates globally that can be attributed to the expansion of the FIFA World Cup to 48 teams. The positive impact must be supported by data from reputable sources, such as FIFA, national soccer federations, or major sports research organizations, indicating a measurable increase in youth participation in soccer in various countries. The increase must be statistically significant and should be based on youth participation metrics collected post-2026 World Cup. Reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) that analyze this impact will also be considered credible evidence. Temporary spikes in participation due to specific events or promotions will not count unless they show a sustained increase in participation rates.

metadata.source_question: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams result in a notable increase in sponsorship revenue for FIFA by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, FIFA reports a notable increase in sponsorship revenue directly attributed to the expansion of the FIFA World Cup to 48 teams. A 'notable increase' is defined as an increase of at least 20% in sponsorship revenue compared to the last World Cup held with 32 teams (2018). This increase must be confirmed in FIFA's official financial statements or through credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, or Reuters). The increase must be directly linked to the expansion and not influenced by other factors such as general market growth or other tournaments. In the event of ambiguity, the resolution will rely on FIFA's official communication regarding the impact of the expansion on sponsorship revenue.

metadata.source_question: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?

title: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, South Korea is recognized as the leader in global digital governance based on the following criteria: 
- South Korea must have implemented comprehensive digital governance policies that are adopted and followed by at least 75% of its population, as verified by government reports and independent surveys. 
- South Korea must hold a prominent position in international digital governance forums, such as the OECD and G20, where it leads discussions and initiatives on digital policy, cybersecurity, and data privacy. 
- The country must be acknowledged in at least three reputable international reports or rankings (e.g., by the World Economic Forum, UN, or similar organizations) as the top nation in digital governance practices. 
- Significant collaborations or partnerships with at least three other countries in establishing global digital standards must be in place, with documented agreements and initiatives. 
In the absence of clear consensus, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will Ukraine achieve a membership action plan with NATO by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Ukraine has been officially granted a Membership Action Plan (MAP) by NATO. The resolution will be based on an official announcement from NATO confirming the MAP status for Ukraine. The MAP must include specific commitments and timelines for Ukraine's integration into NATO, as outlined in NATO's official documentation. If Ukraine is granted a MAP but it is limited to specific conditions or timelines that do not align with NATO's standard procedures, the question will resolve as No. Additionally, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the grant of the MAP will suffice in the absence of an official announcement.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

title: Will Ukraine resolve its territorial disputes with Russia before joining NATO?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, Ukraine has officially resolved its territorial disputes with Russia through a binding agreement that is recognized by both parties and the international community. The resolution must involve clear terms regarding the status of the disputed territories and must be confirmed by a reputable international organization or a consensus of major news outlets (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). In the absence of such an agreement, any unilateral declarations or temporary ceasefires will not count towards the resolution of this question.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

title: Will Ukraine hold a referendum on NATO membership before 2027?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2027, Ukraine holds an official referendum on NATO membership that is recognized and reported by credible sources, including major news organizations such as BBC, The Guardian, and Reuters. The referendum must be conducted in accordance with Ukrainian law and must involve a clear question regarding Ukraine's membership in NATO. The results must be officially announced and made available to the public. Any unofficial polls or surveys will not count towards this question's resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?

title: Will any international sporting event be held in a country under sanctions by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, any international sporting event (including but not limited to the Olympics, World Cup, or continental championships) is officially hosted in a country currently under international sanctions imposed by the United Nations or the European Union. The event must be recognized by the relevant international sporting federation and must take place in the country in question, not in a neutral location. The sanctions must be in effect at the time of the event. Temporary exemptions or special permissions granted for specific events do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will Formula 1 expand to new countries that are currently not on the calendar by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Formula 1 has officially announced and scheduled races in countries that are not currently included in the Formula 1 calendar as of 2023. The announcement must be made by Formula 1 Management and must include specific dates and locations for the races. The races must be confirmed and not merely proposed or under consideration. In the event that multiple countries are added, the question resolves as Yes if at least one new country is confirmed for the 2025 season. Temporary or exhibition events do not count towards this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?

title: Will there be a significant change in international sanctions policy affecting sports by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a significant change in international sanctions policy affecting sports is officially enacted by at least one major governing body (e.g., the United Nations, European Union, or a major sports federation such as FIFA or the International Olympic Committee). A 'significant change' is defined as: 1) The lifting or imposition of sanctions that directly impacts the participation of athletes or teams in international competitions; 2) Changes in eligibility criteria for athletes or teams from sanctioned nations; or 3) A formal change in the rules governing international sports events that affects how sanctions are applied. The change must be documented in official announcements or resolutions from the governing bodies and reported by at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). Temporary measures or discussions do not count towards this question's resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?

title: Will a Formula 1 team be sponsored by a company from a sanctioned country by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a Formula 1 team has an official sponsorship agreement with a company that is based in a country currently under international sanctions as defined by the United Nations or the European Union. The sponsorship must be publicly announced and confirmed through credible sources, including official Formula 1 communications or major news outlets (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). Any sponsorship that is temporary, event-specific, or limited to a specific race does not count. If multiple teams are sponsored by such companies, the question will still resolve as Yes, provided that at least one team has a formal and ongoing sponsorship agreement.

metadata.source_question: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?

title: Will any state-level legislation regarding nuclear safety standards be enacted before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if any state in the United States enacts legislation regarding nuclear safety standards before January 1, 2025. The legislation must be officially signed into law and published in a recognized legal database or state government website. The term 'nuclear safety standards' refers to regulations that govern the operation, maintenance, and safety protocols of nuclear power plants and related facilities. This includes any updates or modifications to existing standards. Legislation that is proposed but not enacted, or that is enacted but subsequently repealed or invalidated, will not count towards a Yes resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

title: Will there be a major public safety incident related to nuclear facilities in the US before 2025?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, any of the following incidents occur at a nuclear facility in the United States:
- A significant release of radioactive material that poses a threat to public health or safety, as determined by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) or the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).
- An incident that results in a fatality or serious injury to workers or the public due to operational failures or accidents at a nuclear facility.
- A major security breach at a nuclear facility that leads to unauthorized access to nuclear materials or poses a credible threat to public safety.

The incidents must be reported and verified by the NRC, or acknowledged by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). Minor incidents or operational issues that do not result in public harm or significant safety threats do not count towards this question's resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

title: Will international nuclear safety standards influence US legislation by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United States Congress passes legislation that incorporates international nuclear safety standards into its regulatory framework. The legislation must explicitly reference and implement these standards, which are defined by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and other recognized international bodies. The legislation must be signed into law by the President of the United States. In the absence of new legislation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) indicating a significant influence of international nuclear safety standards on existing or proposed legislation will also suffice for a Yes resolution. If the legislation is passed but does not effectively implement the standards, the question will resolve as No.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

title: Will the US government increase funding for nuclear safety research by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the US government officially announces an increase in funding for nuclear safety research compared to the funding levels established in the fiscal year 2024. The increase must be documented in an official budget proposal or appropriation bill passed by Congress. The funding increase must be at least 10% over the 2024 levels to qualify. This question resolves as No if there is no official announcement or if the funding remains the same or decreases.

metadata.source_question: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?

title: Will the European Union increase funding for nuclear waste research by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the European Union has officially increased its funding for nuclear waste research compared to the funding levels in 2023. The increase must be documented in official EU budgetary reports or announcements, and it must be at least a 10% increase in real terms, adjusted for inflation. The funding increase must be specifically allocated for nuclear waste research projects and not part of broader funding for nuclear energy or other related areas. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the funding increase will suffice for resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?

title: Will any EU member state adopt a national nuclear waste management policy before 2028?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2027, any member state of the European Union has officially adopted and implemented a national policy for the management of nuclear waste. The policy must include provisions for the safe storage, disposal, and management of nuclear waste, and must be publicly available and recognized by the national government. The policy should be in compliance with the European Union's regulations on nuclear waste management and be reported by reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). Temporary measures or pilot projects do not count; the policy must represent a formal, long-term commitment by the state.

metadata.source_question: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?

title: Will the European Union achieve a consensus on nuclear energy regulations by 2032?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2032, the European Union has officially adopted a comprehensive regulatory framework regarding nuclear energy that is supported by a majority of its member states. The framework must include clear guidelines on safety standards, waste management, and investment in nuclear technologies. The consensus must be documented in an official EU publication or announcement, and supported by credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). The resolution will not be affected by individual member states' decisions to opt-out of nuclear energy but will be based on the collective agreement of the EU as a whole.

metadata.source_question: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?

title: Will the European Union establish a centralized nuclear waste storage facility by 2035?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2035, the European Union has officially established a centralized nuclear waste storage facility that is operational and designed for the long-term storage of nuclear waste from member states. The facility must be recognized and approved by the European Commission, and construction must be completed with all necessary safety and regulatory approvals in place. The facility's operational status must be confirmed by an official announcement from the European Commission or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). Temporary or pilot projects do not count towards this resolution; the facility must be fully functional and intended for long-term use.

metadata.source_question: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?

title: Will public opinion in EU countries support nuclear energy as a solution to climate change by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, at least 50% of the population in a majority of EU member states (15 out of 27) express support for the use of nuclear energy as a solution to climate change in a reputable public opinion poll. The poll must be conducted by a recognized polling organization and published in a major media outlet (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). Support for nuclear energy must be defined as those who agree with the statement that nuclear energy is an important part of the solution to climate change. The question will resolve as No if the majority of EU member states do not meet this criterion, regardless of individual country support levels.

metadata.source_question: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a higher number of participating countries in future tournaments by 2034?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2034, the FIFA World Cup, having expanded to 48 teams starting from the 2026 tournament, sees an increase in the number of participating countries in at least one subsequent tournament compared to the number of participating countries in the last tournament before the expansion (which had 32 teams). The increase must be recognized by FIFA and reported in official documentation. Additionally, if any tournament held after 2026 has more than 32 participating countries, this will satisfy the resolution criteria. The resolution will not count temporary or special invitations that are not part of the regular qualification process.

metadata.source_question: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams result in an increase in sponsorship revenue for FIFA by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, FIFA reports an increase in sponsorship revenue directly attributable to the expansion of the FIFA World Cup to 48 teams. The increase must be measurable and compared to sponsorship revenue from the last World Cup held with 32 teams (2018). The revenue data must be publicly disclosed in FIFA's financial reports or confirmed by reputable financial news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). The increase must be at least 10% over the previous World Cup's sponsorship revenue to qualify as a significant increase. If FIFA's reporting is ambiguous or disputed, the question will resolve as No.

metadata.source_question: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to the introduction of new soccer markets by 2032?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2032, at least two new soccer markets are officially recognized as having professional leagues or significant national representation in international soccer tournaments as a direct result of the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams. A 'new soccer market' is defined as a country or region that has not previously had a significant presence in international soccer competitions, specifically those that have not qualified for a World Cup or continental championship in the last 20 years. The recognition must come from FIFA or a reputable soccer governing body, and the new markets must demonstrate a sustainable soccer infrastructure, including a professional league and national team participation in FIFA-sanctioned tournaments. Reports from credible sources such as FIFA, BBC, The Guardian, or similar outlets will be accepted as evidence.

metadata.source_question: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams cause a significant increase in youth soccer participation globally by 2035?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2035, there is credible evidence indicating a significant increase in youth soccer participation globally, attributable to the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams. A significant increase is defined as at least a 15% rise in the number of registered youth players in at least 50 countries, compared to the numbers reported in 2022. The increase must be documented by reputable sources such as FIFA reports, national soccer federations, or recognized sports research organizations. Additionally, the connection between the World Cup expansion and the rise in participation must be supported by surveys or studies published in peer-reviewed journals or recognized by major sports media outlets (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, ESPN). This question resolves as No if the increase does not meet the specified criteria or if the increase is attributed to factors other than the World Cup expansion.

metadata.source_question: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?

title: Will South Korea establish a comprehensive digital identity system by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the South Korean government has officially established a comprehensive digital identity system that allows citizens to securely verify their identity online across multiple platforms, including government services, financial institutions, and private sector services. The system must include features such as biometric verification, secure data storage, and user consent management. The establishment of the system must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The system must be fully operational and not in a pilot or trial phase.

metadata.source_question: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?

title: Will South Korea lead the development of international digital privacy standards by 2028?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, South Korea has been recognized as the leading nation in the development of international digital privacy standards by at least three major international organizations or forums focused on digital privacy, such as the International Organization for Standardization (ISO), the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF), or the Global Privacy Assembly. The recognition must be based on formal agreements, publications, or resolutions that establish South Korea's role as a primary contributor to these standards. Additionally, the standards must be adopted or endorsed by at least five countries, including South Korea, to qualify for this resolution. If South Korea is a significant contributor but not the recognized leader, the question will resolve as No.

metadata.source_question: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?

title: Will South Korea's digital governance model be adopted by at least three other countries by 2032?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2032, at least three countries have officially adopted a digital governance model that is substantially similar to South Korea's current digital governance model as of 2023. The adoption must be confirmed through official government announcements or reputable news sources (such as BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, etc.). The model must include key elements such as e-government services, digital identity systems, and data privacy regulations that align with South Korea's framework. If a country adopts a modified version of the model, it will still count towards the resolution as long as the core principles remain intact. Countries that only implement pilot programs or temporary measures do not count towards this question's resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?

title: Will South Korea implement nationwide 5G infrastructure by 2024?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, South Korea has fully implemented nationwide 5G infrastructure that is operational and available to the general public in all major urban areas. The implementation must be confirmed by official government announcements or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). The infrastructure must support the standards set by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) for 5G networks, including peak data rates of at least 20 Gbps and latency of less than 1 millisecond. If there is partial implementation, the question will resolve as Yes only if the government has a clear plan for full nationwide coverage and timeline for completion.

metadata.source_question: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?

title: Will South Korea host a major international summit on digital governance by 2026?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, South Korea has officially hosted a major international summit focused on digital governance. The summit must involve participation from at least five countries and have a clear agenda addressing topics such as data privacy, cybersecurity, digital economy, and international regulations on digital technologies. The confirmation of the summit must be reported by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and must include official government documentation or announcements. If the summit is postponed or canceled, the question will resolve as No.

metadata.source_question: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?

title: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, credible evidence demonstrates that Microsoft's carbon negative pledge has led to a measurable reduction in global CO2 levels. The reduction must be at least 1% of global CO2 emissions compared to levels recorded in 2020, as reported by authoritative sources such as the Global Carbon Project or the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). The impact must be attributed directly to Microsoft's initiatives and not to other external factors or global events. The evidence must be supported by peer-reviewed research or official reports from reputable organizations (e.g., UN, World Resources Institute) that analyze the effectiveness of corporate carbon pledges on global emissions.

title: Will other major tech companies follow Microsoft's lead in committing to carbon negative pledges by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, at least three major technology companies (defined as companies with a market capitalization over $10 billion) publicly commit to carbon negative pledges. A carbon negative pledge means that the company commits to removing more carbon dioxide from the atmosphere than it emits, with specific targets and timelines outlined in their sustainability reports or official announcements. The commitments must be verifiable and publicly available, and they must include measurable goals for carbon removal. Companies must be recognized as major players in the tech industry, such as those listed in the Fortune 500 or similar reputable sources. The commitment must be confirmed by credible news reports from at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). Temporary initiatives or commitments that do not have a long-term strategy or measurable impact will not count towards this resolution.

metadata.source_question: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?

title: Will Microsoft's carbon negative initiatives lead to a measurable decrease in CO2 emissions in the tech sector by 2028?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, there is clear and measurable evidence that Microsoft’s carbon negative initiatives have resulted in a quantifiable decrease in CO2 emissions across the tech sector. The evidence must be based on credible reports from independent environmental organizations or peer-reviewed studies that demonstrate a reduction in CO2 emissions attributed to Microsoft's initiatives. The reduction must be statistically significant, defined as a decrease of at least 10% in CO2 emissions from the baseline year of 2020. The resolution will also consider the overall impact of Microsoft's initiatives on the tech sector, including partnerships and collaborations with other companies in the industry. Reports must be published in reputable outlets, such as the New York Times, BBC, or scientific journals that focus on environmental science.

metadata.source_question: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?
